bullet_points: Load the merger tree dataset from the specified file using PyTorch.
Verify the integrity of the loaded data: check for missing, NaN, or inconsistent values in the node features across all trees.
Document any data issues found and how they are handled (e.g., imputation, removal).
Extract node features (mass, concentration, vmax, scale factor) for all trees.
Apply logarithmic transformation to mass and vmax.
Standardize all features (zero mean, unit variance) using statistics from the full dataset.
Save preprocessed data for subsequent steps.
For each merger tree, identify the main branch using the provided mask.
For each node along the main branch, extract k-hop subgraphs (experiment with k=1,2,3).
For each value of k, document the impact on subgraph size and structure, including summary statistics (e.g., average number of nodes/edges per subgraph).
For each subgraph, extract the node feature matrix and pad/truncate as needed to a fixed size suitable for QTT.
Organize subgraph feature matrices for QTT processing.
sub_tasks.sub_task: Subgraph Extraction, k-hop Documentation, and Preparation for QTT

bullet_points: Apply QTT decomposition to each subgraph’s feature matrix, experimenting with different QTT ranks.
For each QTT rank, document the impact on compression quality and feature representation (e.g., reconstruction error, feature vector size).
Flatten and concatenate QTT tensor cores to form a fixed-length QTT feature vector for each subgraph.
Aggregate QTT feature vectors for each merger tree (e.g., mean pooling across main branch nodes).
Save the aggregated QTT feature vectors for all trees.
sub_tasks.sub_task: QTT Decomposition, Rank Experimentation, and Feature Engineering

bullet_points: Split the dataset into training, validation, and test sets (e.g., 70/15/15 or 60/20/20 split).
Use the aggregated QTT feature vectors as input to a regression model (Random Forest or Gradient Boosting) to predict final halo mass at z=0.
Train baseline models using traditional features (e.g., mean/max/variance of node features along the main branch).
Evaluate models using MSE, MAE, and R² on validation and test sets.
Generate plots: predicted vs. true mass, residuals, feature importances, and performance comparisons.
sub_tasks.sub_task: Dataset Splitting, Regression Modeling, and Baseline Comparison

bullet_points: Visualize distributions of QTT features and compare to traditional features.
Produce dimensionality reduction plots (PCA/t-SNE) of both QTT-based and traditional feature spaces, colored by halo mass, to highlight differences in representation.
Visualize selected subgraphs with QTT feature overlays.
Generate all plots needed for interpretation and reporting.
Summarize and interpret the quantitative results from regression models, including performance metrics and feature importances.
Discuss the physical meaning and utility of QTT-based features compared to traditional features.
Reference and interpret all generated plots, highlighting key findings and insights, including the impact of k and QTT rank.

Discuss the limitations of the current approach (e.g., dataset size, CPU constraints, feature selection) and suggest potential future directions (e.g., scaling to larger datasets, incorporating more cosmological parameters).
Provide a comprehensive Results section suitable for inclusion in a scientific paper or report.
